DOC.HEAD: Grenada's Blaize, Staunch U.S. Ally, Dead at 71
Eds: LEADS throughout with new material and editing, UPDATING with new prime minister named, other. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Herbert Blaize, who hailed the 1983 U.S.-led invasion of Grenada as a ``rescue mission'' that restored democracy and who won the election that followed, died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 71. Sir Paul Scoon, the British governor-general, named Deputy Prime Minister Ben Jones to succeed Blaize until general elections are held. Scoon appealed for calm and asked the nation to lend the new prime minister their support. He noted that elections for a new government will be held shortly, but set no date. Grenada, the most southerly of the Windward Islands in the Caribbean, was due to hold general elections by March 1990, but the vote could be advanced. Blaize suffered for years from prostate cancer and crippling arthritis. He died at his official Mount Royal residence, Scoon announced. No cause of death was stated. Blaize walked with the aid of a cane and received regular cancer treatment at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington. He had become increasingly frail and was unable to raise his voice above a whisper at a political luncheon this month. He was elected prime minister on Dec. 3, 1984, in the first election after U.S. troops, supported by a small Caribbean force, invaded Grenada on Oct. 24-28, 1983, and ousted a Marxist military junta that had seized power and assassinated Prime Minister Maurice Bishop. The invasion was widely criticized abroad as a breach of Grenada's sovereignty, but Blaize said it saved Grenada from a brutal clique that placed the 100,000 residents under a 24-hour curfew. ``It was God who sent the Americans and Caribbean forces to deliver them (Grenadians),'' he said in an interview with The Associated Press in October 1988. Scoon, Queen Elizabeth II's representative in the former British colony, called the main opposition members of Parliament in for talks Tuesday on forming a successor government. Blaize had clung to power despite failing health, political bickering that cost him the party leadership, and a growing public clamor over what many called his authoritarian style of leadership. Herbert Augustus Blaize, born on Feb. 26, 1918, the son of a laborer, on the Grenadian offshore island of Carriacou, became leader of the Grenada National Party in 1959, and headed the government from 1962 to 1967. Grenada became independent from Britain in 1974. After the 1983 invasion, a coalition of centrist parties was cobbled together under the banner of the New National Party to prevent a possible election victory by Sir Eric Gairy, a populist who was ousted as prime minister in a 1979 leftist coup. Gairy's former administration had been riven by charges of corruption and repression. Blaize, a Reagan administration favorite, was chosen to head the coalition because of his previous government experience. His popularity declined with the government's inability to improve the economy and put a dent in Grenada's 20-percent unemployment rate. Since the invasion, the United States has pumped more than $100 million into Grenada, but a widely expected foreign investment boom never materialized and U.S. aid dropped off. Blaize is survived by his wife, Venetia, and their three sons and three daughters. A memorial service will be held Friday at St. George's Anglican Church, with funeral and burial Sunday in Carriacou.
